chapter.htmlHeader: Symptoms suggestive of gynaecological cancers
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Table 2. Symptoms suggestive of gynaecological cancers.

SymptomPossible cancerReferral recommendation
Appearance of cervix consistent with cervical cancerCervicalConsider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
Blood glucose levels high with visible haematuria in women age 55 years and overEndometrialConsider a direct access ultrasound scan
Haemoglobin levels low with visible haematuria in women age 55 years and overEndometrialConsider a direct access ultrasound scan
Haematuria (visible) with low haemoglobin levels or thrombocytosis or high blood glucose levels or unexplained vaginal discharge in women age 55 years and overEndometrialConsider a direct access ultrasound scan
Post-menopausal bleeding in women age 55 years and over (unexplained vaginal bleeding more than 12 months after menstruation has stopped because of the menopause)EndometrialRefer women using a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
Post-menopausal bleeding in women age under 55 years (unexplained vaginal bleeding more than 12 months after menstruation has stopped because of the menopause)EndometrialConsider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
Thrombocytosis with visible haematuria or vaginal discharge (unexplained) in women age 55 years and overEndometrialConsider a direct access ultrasound scan
Vaginal discharge (unexplained) either at first presentation or with thrombocytosis or with haematuria, in women age 55 years and overEndometrialConsider a direct access ultrasound scan
Appetite loss or early satiety (persistent or frequent – particularly more than 12 times per month) in women, especially if age 50 years and overOvarian

Carry out appropriate investigatons*

Measure serum CA125*

Abdominal distension (persistent or frequent – particularly more than 12 times per month) in women, especially if age 50 years and overOvarian

Carry out appropriate investigations*

Measure serum CA125*

Ascites and/or a pelvic or abdominal mass identified by physical examination (which is not obviously uterine fibroids) in womenOvarianRefer urgently* (within 2 weeks)
Abdominal or pelvic mass identified by physical examination (which is not obviously uterine fibroids) in womenOvarianRefer urgently* (within 2 weeks)
Abdominal or pelvic pain (persistent or frequent – particularly more than 12 times per month) in women, especially if age 50 years and overOvarian

Carry out appropriate investigations*

Measure serum CA125*

Irritable bowel syndrome symptoms within the last 12 months in women age 50 years and overOvarian

Carry out appropriate tests for ovarian cancer, because irritable bowel syndrome rarely presents for the first time in women of this age*

Measure serum CA125*

Change in bowel habit (unexplained) in womenOvarian

Consider carrying out appropriate investigations*

Measure serum CA125*

Fatigue (unexplained) in womenOvarian

Carry out appropriate investigations*

Measure serum CA125*

Urinary urgency and/or frequency (increased and persistent or frequent – particularly more than 12 times per month) in women, especially if age 50 years and overOvarian

Carry out tests in primary care*

Measure serum CA125 in primary care*

Weight loss (unexplained) in womenOvarian

Consider carrying out tests in primary care*

Measure serum CA125 in primary care*

Serum CA125 resultsOvarian

If serum CA125 is 35 IU/ml or greater, arrange an ultrasound scan of the abdomen and pelvis*

Normal serum CA125 (less than 35 IU/ml), or CA125 of 35 IU/ml or greater but a normal ultrasound: assess carefully for other clinical causes of her symptoms and investigate if appropriate. If no other clinical cause is apparent, advise her to return if symptoms become more frequent and/or persistent*

Ultrasound suggests ovarian cancerOvarian

Refer urgently for further investigation*

Ultrasound normal with CA125 of 35 IU/ml or greaterOvarian

Assess carefully for other clinical causes if symptoms and investigate if appropriate*

If no other clinical cause is apparent, advise to return if symptoms become more frequent and/or persistent*

Vaginal mass (unexplained and palpable) in or at the entrance to the vaginaVaginalConsider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
Vulval bleeding (unexplained) in womenVulvalConsider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
Vulval lump or ulceration (unexplained)VulvalConsider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks)
* The recommendations for ovarian cancer apply to women aged 18 years and over
Data from: [NICE, 2015]

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Referral for suspected gynaecological cancer

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This is a direct implementation of the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015].
